items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.22 m and is falling slowly.  The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.14 m and is stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load if this level exceeds 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m. Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. The River Yeo at Muchelney has been decreasing throughout yesterday, 01/11/21, into today. We are continuing to monitor the situation closely.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Wednesday, 03/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Water levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land in locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Further showers are expected today, 01/11/2021 and into tomorrow, 02/11/2021, however we expect levels to continue to fall slowly. We are monitoring the situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain high at Low Nibthwaite as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Dunnerdale, Duddon Bridge, Broughton-in-Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Soutergate, Coniston, Ulverston, Dalton-in-Furness and Barrow-in-Furness areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Duddon, Kirkby Pool, Soutergate Beck, Church Beck, Yewdale Beck, Coniston Water, River Crake, Town Beck, Dragley Beck, Poaka Beck, Mill Beck and their tributaries. Further showers are expected today, 01/11/2021 and into tomorrow, 02/11/2021.  We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated this tomorrow, 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels will remain high on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to recent rainfall. Consequently, risk of flooding to low lying land and roads remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Buttermere, Lorton Valley, Cockermouth, Branthwaite, Bridgefoot, Camerton, Barepot and Workington areas. Further showers are expected today, 01/11/2021 and into tomorrow, 02/11/2021. This will keep levels high on the River Cocker, Whit Beck, River Derwent, River Marron, Lostrigg Beck and their tributaries. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

River and lake levels are high as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few days. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Bampton, Patterdale, Glenridding, Dockray, Pooley Bridge, Dacre, Eamont Bridge and Penrith areas. High river and lake levels are still possible on the River Lowther, Haweswater Beck, Goldrill Beck, Grisedale Beck, Glenridding Beck, Aira Beck, Ullswater, River Eamont, Dacre Beck, Thacka Beck and their tributaries. Further showers are expected today, 01/11/2021 and into tomorrow, 02/11/2021, however we expect levels to continue to fall slowly.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high as a result of recent rainfall.  These include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, particularly from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Further showers are expected today, 01/11/2021 and into tomorrow, 02/11/2021, however we expect levels to continue to fall slowly. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

The levels of Derwent Water remains high following recent heavy rainfall, although they are now beginning to fall slowly. Further showers are expected today Monday, 01/11/2021. Areas that continue to be at risk of flooding include low-lying land bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place for several days as the lake level will remain high. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will update this message tomorrow morning 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling this evening as rainfall eases.
Some further rainfall is forecast but no property flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message: River levels remain high at the Beggearn Huish river gauge.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 02/11/21.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries.  Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Wednesday, 03/11/21, or as the situation changes.

River Levels in Earby and Glusburn Becks are falling and are expected to do so for the rest of today, Monday 01/11/2021. Please continue to avoid using low lying footpaths and be aware that fast flowing water can still be a danger, even as river level falls.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.4 m and is falling slowly. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.61 m and is falling slowly. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m. Pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. There are further light showers forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Compton Dando river gauge following  heavy rainfall over the weekend. We expect flooding to affect the fords on Mill Lane and Pilgrims Way in Chew Stoke and The Batch and Dumpers Lane in Chew Magna.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. River levels can rise very quickly in response to further rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, Tuesday 02/11/21 or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling slowly but remain high at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high into tomorrow Wednesday 03/11/21. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 7 pm today, Tuesday 02/11/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Castle Farm river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.   
Showers are expected over the next 24 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels remain high on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today 02/11/2021 , especially in areas closest to the watercourses at Passfield Mill. A  mostly dry day is expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is still high and rising in some communities, following Sunday morning’s rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens, rural roads and isolated properties near to Fittleworth. We predict the river will only rise a few centimetres, before beginning to fall by 20:00 01/11/2021 in Fittleworth. The river has now peaked and returned to near normal in Liss, Sheet, Iping, Stedham, Midhurst and Lodsbridge. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next few days and we do not expect the river to rise significantly as a result of these showers. Please keep flood resilience products in place while minor flood impacts remain. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts. We will update this message by 12:00 02/11/2021.

items.message:

River levels are high on the River Evenlode following heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today (02/11/21), especially in the Shipton-Under-Wychwood area. Levels on the River Glyme remain below the flood risk threshold.
The forecast is for a dry day. River levels have now dropped below the flood risk threshold upstream of Shipton-Under-Wychwood. Levels in the Shipton-Under-Wychwood area are now slowly falling and will continue to fall during the day.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please be aware of standing water on the floodplain and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated this evening, Tuesday 02/11/21, or as the situation changes.

Areas still at risk include River Wyre, River Cocker, Pilling Water and other watercourses from Catterall to Fleetwood, including St Michaels and Great Eccleston and Preesall.
No property flooding is expected. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.    No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

Some rainfall is forecast and we will continue to monitor levels closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River Levels across most of the lower River Calder are falling and will continue to do so over the next few days. Although the river has yet to peak at Wakefield and downstream, levels will not reach levels of concern with no further significant rainfall expected today or tomorrow.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Irwell due to heavy rainfall. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. floodArea.county: Bolton, Bury, Manchester, Oldham, Rochdale, Salford, Tameside, Trafford

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Irwell due to heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Rivers Irk and Medlock, Wince and Worsley Brooks and their tributaries today, on Monday 1 November 2021. Further heavy rainfall is forecast today, on 1/11/2021. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Ouse remains in force due to rising levels on the river through York. Levels are rising in response to heavy rainfall on the Pennines over the last few days. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south, as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Levels in York are forecast to peak during the early hours of Tuesday morning, 02/11/2021. Please see GOV.UK website for the latest river levels and forecast for York. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Peaks: - Crew Green Steady at 5.29m. Predicted Peaks:- Montford 4.4m to 4.6m this morning, Welshbridge 2.2m to 2.4m this morning, Buildwas 3.0m to 3.3m this evening, Bridgnorth 2.0m to 2.4m Wednesday. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until 03/11/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Mersey due to heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around Micker, Cringle, Sinderland and Poynton Brooks and their tributaries today, on Monday 1 November 2021. Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout the rest of today, and we will continue to monitor river levels closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby has been issued as levels are rising steadily in York due to heavy rainfall upstream in the Pennines over the last few days. Areas near the River Ouse with low-lying land are expected to be most affected, particularly around the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. The river level in Naburn at 01:00 on Tuesday 02/11/2021 is 2.35m and levels are forecast to peak early on Tuesday morning, 02/11/2021. Levels downstream at Selby Westmill are not currently of concern. No significant rainfall is expected in the next couple of days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Please see GOV.UK website for the latest river levels and forecast for York. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels, and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, be aware of your surroundings, and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, on Tuesday 2nd November, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Sankey due to heavy rainfall. Consequently, we believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around Black, Barkers, Windle and Whittle Brooks and their tributaries today, on Monday 1 November 2021. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels, and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, be aware of your surroundings, and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, on Tuesday 2nd November, or as the situation changes.

The flood warning for the River Ouse at Naburn Lock has been issued due to rising river levels on the Ouse following recent rainfall. The River Ouse in York is currently 2.79m and is expected to peak at around 2.8m at around 5am on Tuesday morning, 02/11/2021. Areas most at risk are the Naburn Lock area. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: The flood warning for riverside properties in York has been issued as levels are rising on the River Ouse following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is possible in the early hours of Tuesday, 02/11/2021. The River Ouse in York is forecast to peak at roughly 2.8m at around 5am on Tuesday, 02/11/2021. No further significant rainfall is expected overnight. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Whinney Brook and Dovers Brook at Maghull, around Sefton Lane and the Waste Transfer Station
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
No property flooding is expected.
Further showery rain is forecast through Tuesday but this is not expected to cause river levels to rise further.
River levels are now falling steadily, but still remain quite high in some locations and a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent has now been issued. Levels have risen in the headwaters of the River Derwent as a result of heavy rainfall on Sunday 31st October. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected during Tuesday 2nd November. Areas most at risk are low-lying land and roads around Low Marishes. Levels will remain high in this area during Tuesday. Levels in Malton are not currently of concern. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. Further rain is forecast later this week. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Lower Stour at Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
River levels are rising steadily on the Lower Dorset Stour due to the weekendrainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites.
Flooding is expected at Redhill and Wheatplot Home Sites from 10:00 AM on 02/11/2021.
No further rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days.
River levels are rising at the Throop, Wimborne A31 gauge.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one
Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 02/11/2021, or as the situation changes.
